thread.title: UPDATE 1-Zodiac Aero factory blast shows risks in supply chain
thread.title_full: UPDATE 1-Zodiac Aero factory blast shows risks in supply chain | Reuters

author: Reuters
title: UPDATE 1-Zodiac Aero factory blast shows risks in supply chain
text:
(Adds details about industry supply chain, Bombardier comment)
By Alwyn Scott and Cyril Altmeyer
July 16 (Reuters) - Zodiac Aerospace said it is considering moving machinery from a U.S. factory crippled by a powerful explosion on Tuesday so that it can continue making aircraft interior composite panels needed by the booming aviation industry.
Zodiac has "buffer inventory" of the materials that it can use in the short term, a spokesman told Reuters on Thursday.
"If the situation were to last in the longer term, it is not known yet whether Zodiac will be able to produce panels internally or would have to buy them externally," the spokesman said.
The blast at the plant in Newport, Washington, on Tuesday night fractured concrete pillars, blew out windows and caused a floor to collapse, making the building unsafe to occupy, authorities said.
The damaged plant makes "prepreg," a thin resin-soaked sheeting material that is glued to either side of a thicker honeycomb core to make rigid wall panels for lavatories, galleys and other aircraft interior parts.
Boeing Co said it was working closely with Zodiac to reduce any impact from the factory shutdown on its aircraft assembly operations. Airbus did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
Still, concerns about the closed Zodiac facility, one of more than 30 Zodiac has in the U.S., reveal how vulnerable the aircraft industry is to disruptions in the overall supply chain.
Boeing and Airbus are churning out more than 100 jetliners a month, a record pace aimed at reducing an eight-year backlog of orders.
Their assembly plants rely on a steady, just-in-time flow of millions of parts shipped from thousands of suppliers around the globe. Some parts come from only one or two suppliers.
Zodiac's prepreg factory supplies at least five other Zodiac factory facilities in Washington state and California that make seat shells and cabin interiors.
Earlier this year, Zodiac failed to deliver seats on time, causing late deliveries of Boeing and Airbus aircraft.
The costly error drew a public scolding from plane makers and forced Zodiac to warn in June that its profits would suffer.
Plane makers Bombardier and Embraer were also affected by the earlier problems at Zodiac's cabin interiors business.
On Thursday, Bombardier said Zodiac supplies its Q400 turboprop and CRJ programs, and that it did not expect production would be affected by the plant shutdown. Embraer did not immediately respond to requests for comment. (Reporting by Cyril Altmeyer in Paris, Alwyn Scott in New York, Allison Martell in Toronto and Brad Haynes in Sao Paulo; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama, Bernard Orr)
